chapter.title: Web Content Control
chapter.para:
The Web Content Control is identified by the
symbol. If the Web Content Control Appliance is not installed, please refer to for installation instructions.

As its name implies, the Web Content Control Appliance is used to filter web traffic to your protected network for inappropriate content. Unlike other software appliances, the the criteria used by the Web Content Control Appliance can be seen as subjective. Inappropriate content may be executables to some, while to others it is web sites discussing Illegal Drugs.

sect1.title: Administrative Interface
sect1.para: The interface for the Web Content Control is presented as three tabs. The first two tabs, covered in sections and , allow control over blocked and permitted content. The last tab, discussed in , allows administrators to view events.

sect2.title: Block Lists
sect2.para: The Block List tab presents administrators the ability to modify the four major criteria of content filtering: by category, URL, MIME Type and File Extension. Refer to the section for each sub-tab for more detail.

sect3.title: Categories
sect3.para: The Categories tab, as shown in , allows the administrator the ability to block categories of sites. The names of the various categories and a description are presented in the table.

When a user within the protected network browses a site selected in the Category tab, they will be presented with an error page. The page will inform the user that their request has been blocked by the Web Content Control Appliance. They will also be told the category (Web Mail, Gambling, etc) of the site in question.

sect3.title: URLs
sect3.para: The block list of URLs is shown in

The URL block list is initially empty. When adding a new entry, you enter a URL which encompasses an exact match or any URLs matching that prefix (see for more details on URL matching). The category column can contain any category of your choosing (it does not have to correspond to the predefined categories discussed in ).

sect3.title: MIME Types
sect3.para: The MIME Types tab lets administrators block the downloading of content by MIME type. The interface for the MIME Types tab is shown in .
As shown in , the list contains the most common MIME types. By default, they are no MIME types blocked. To block a particular MIME Type, check the block box.

sect3.title: File Extensions
sect3.para: The File Extensions Tab, as shown in , allows Administrators to cause the download of files to be blocked based on file extension (e.g. .exe).
As shown in , the list contains the most common file extensions. No file extensions are blocked by default. To block a file extension, check the block box.

sect2.title: Pass Lists
sect2.para: As discussed in , the Web Content Control Appliance offers several ways to block inappropriate or malicious traffic from entering your protected network. However, there may be circumstances where you need to bypass these guards for an individual within your company, or a site outside your network.

The Pass List allows individuals and groups to bypass filtering. When traffic is found to match an entry in one of the pass lists, it is not filtered. Passes can be created for various sites, as discussed in , or for individual machines within the protected network as discussed in .

sect3.title: URLs
sect3.para: The pass list of URLs is shown in

The URL pass list is initially empty. When adding a new entry, you enter a URL which encompasses an exact match or any URLs matching that prefix (see for more details on URL matching). The category column can contain any category of your choosing (it does not have to correspond to the predefined categories discussed in ).

sect3.title: Clients
sect3.para: The lets Administrators define sites outside the protected network which will not receive filtering. The Clients Tab lets Administrators define machines within the protected network whose requests will not be filtered. The interface for the client pass list is shown in .

The list shown in is initially empty. As new entries are made, administrators must enter client IP address. The format of the client IP address field is either in Simple IP Address or Network/Netmask format. Note that the category field is only for administrator reference - it need not match up with the predefined categories discussed in .

The Events Tab is another implementation of an Event Log, as described in . The action column describes the action which the ⪚ took on the web request. The client column shows the IP address of the client who made the request.
